TI Endoparasites of wildcats in Croatia.
AU Martinkovic, Franjo
   Sindicic, Magda (magda.sindicic@vef.hr) 
   Lucinger, Snjezana
   Stimac, Iva
   Bujanic, Miljenko
   Zivicnjak, Tatjana
   Jan, Dagny Stojcevic
   Sprem, Nikica
   Popovic, Ratko
   Konjevic, Dean
SO Veterinarski Arhiv
VL 87
IS 6
PS 713-729
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 1
U2 18
AB Reports on the parasitic fauna of wildcats (Fells silvestris) are rare
   and often based on a small sample size, therefore the goal of this
   research was to investigate the prevalence of endoparasites in wildcats
   in Croatia. Necropsy was conducted on 34 adult wildcats killed in
   traffic or provided by hunters following regular hunting operations. All
   animals tested negative for rabies. The contents of the stomach and
   intestine were examined under a microscope. Feces from the rectum were
   analyzed using flotation with a saturated ZnSO, solution, while the
   diaphragm was examined using artificial digestion. Direct
   immunofluorescence was used for the first time to detect Giardia sp.
   cysts in wildcats. All animals were infected with at least one species
   of parasites, while the most diverse infestation included six different
   species ol parasites in a single animal. The following parasite species
   were found (% ol prevalence of adult parasites and their developmental
   stages in all analyzed samples): Taenia taentaelbrmis (55.9%), CapiNaria
   sp. (50%), Toxocara cad (50%), Isospora sp. (29.4%) 9rongylat des sp.
   (23.5%), Giardia sp. (17.6%), Ancylostoma tubaelbrmae (14.7%),
   Physaloptera sp. (11.8%), Hymenolepididae (8.8%), Alaria alata (5.9%),
   Aelurostrongylus a bstrusus (5.9%), Toxascaris leonina (5.9%),
   Trichinella sp. (5.9%), Ivlesocestoides lineatus (5.9%),
   Anoplocephalidae (2.9%), Dipyliclium caninum (2.9%), Trichuris sp.
   (2.9%), Isospora Eimeria sp. (2.9%) and Sarcocystis sp. (2.9'1.4 Among
   those, Eimeria sp., Triclmris sp. eggs, anoplocephalid and hymenolepidid
   type eggs are spurious parasites, coming from ingested prey. Four of the
   identified species have never been previously reported in wildcats
   Giardia sp. SYrongyloides sp., Sarcocystis sp. and Dipylidium caninum.

DT Article
TI A new species of Phyllocomus Grube, 1878 from the Yellow Sea, China
   (Annelida, Ampharetidae).
AU Sui, Jixing
   Li, Xinzheng (lixzh@qdio.ac.cn) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 676
PS 13-19
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the ampharetid genus Phyllocomus, P. chinensis sp. n.,
   is described based on material from the Yellow Sea. The new species is
   distinguished from the known species of this genus by having two
   thoracic regions, with segments of the anterior region (up to thoracic
   chaetiger 10) approximately half as long as those of the posterior
   region, neuropodia of the anterior region are large while those of the
   posterior region become gradually smaller, thoracic neuropodia without
   dorsal cirrus, and abdominal neuropodia with a papillary dorsal cirrus.
   A key to all species of Phyllocomus is given.

DT Article
TI Phytobia (Diptera: Agromyzidae) from Brazil: new species, new record and
   a key to the Neotropical species.
AU de Sousa, Viviane Rodrigues (sousavrodrigues@gmail.com) 
   Couri, Marcia Souto
SO Zoologia
VL 34
PS e12308
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Phytobia Lioy, 1864 flies occur in all continents. There are four
   recorded species of these flies in Brazil, but recent expeditions at
   unexplored areas in the country have revealed that the genus is far more
   diverse than previously known. Based on material collected in the states
   of Mato Grosso, Mato Grosso do Sul, and Rondonia (as part of the
   SISBIOTA Diptera Project), we describe fourteen new species of Phytobia.
   Additionally, we redescribe P. kallima (Frost), previously recorded only
   from Panama, and provide a key to the 32 resulting Neotropical species.
   All descriptions include details and illustrations of the male and
   female terminalia. The speciemens are deposited in the collections of
   Museu de Zoologia, Universidade de Sao Paulo (Sao Paulo, Brazil) and
   Museu Nacional, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (Rio de Janeiro,
   Brazil).
C1 de Sousa, Viviane Rodrigues; Univ Fed Rio de Janeiro, Museu Nacl, Rio De

TI New species and new distributional data on Carabidae (Coleoptera) from
   the Socotra Archipelago.
AU Felix, Ron F.F.L. (Ron.Felix@naturalis.nl) 
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 57
SU S
PS 41-54
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of carabid beetles of the tribe Lebiini are described:
   Glycia socotrana sp. nov., previously mentioned as Glycia cf. spencei
   (Gistel, 1838), from Socotra Island and Abd al Kuri Island; Apristus
   dioscoridus sp. nov. and Mesolestes niger sp. nov., both from Socotra
   Island. Acupalpus (Stenolophidius) posticalis (Putzeys, 1880), Harpalus
   (Cryptophonus) tenebrosus Dejean, 1829, and Metadromius sp. are recorded
   from the Socotra Archipelago for the first time. In addition, new
   distributional data from Socotra are given for several other carabid
   species.

DT Article
TI Histeridae of Socotra (Coleoptera: Histeroidea).
AU Lackner, Tomas (tomaslackner@me.com) 
   Vienna, Pierpaolo
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 57
SU S
PS 55-76
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The histerid beetles (Coleoptera: Histeridae) of Socotra Island (Yemen)
   are reviewed based on the material collected during the Czech
   expeditions undertaken between 2000 and 2012. A total of 20 species are
   recorded, three of which are described herein: Pachycraerus socotrensis
   sp. nov., Liopygus occidentalis sp. nov., and Teretrius (Neoteretrius)
   dispar sp. nov. Hypocaccus virescens Therond, 1963 is transferred from
   the subgenus Baeckmanniolus Reichardt, 1926 to Hypocaccus s. str.
   Thomson, 1867 based on external morphology. Most taxa, albeit determined
   only up to their (sub) generic rank, are recorded from Socotra for the
   first time. Due to poor understanding of their taxonomy, or lack of
   determination keys to the following (sub) genera: Tribalus Erichson,
   1834, Plegaderus (Plegaderus) Erichson, 1834, Acritus (Acritus) LeConte,
   1853, and Teretrius (Teretrius) Erichson, 1834, their representatives
   from Socotra are left without identifi cation pending revisions. The
   Socotran histerid fauna has been found to consist mainly of widely
   distributed African, Arabian/Near Eastern taxa, as well as local
   endemics. The occurrence of the (predominantly Holarctic) genus
   Plegaderus and the exclusively southeast Asian genus Liopygus Lewis,
   1891 in Socotra is highly interesting.

DT Article
TI Canuschiza of Socotra Island (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Melolonthinae)
   Part 2. Canuschiza minuta species group.
AU Sehnal, Richard (richard.sehnal@seznam.cz) 
   Kral, David
   Bezdek, Ales
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 57
SU S
PS 77-86
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Canuschiza minuta Lacroix, 1999 species group of the genus
   Canuschiza Lacroix, 1999 is revised. Canuschiza zerig sp. nov. and
   previously unknown female of C. minuta are described. Variability in
   number of antennomeres observed in females of C. minuta is briefly
   discussed. An identification key to males and females of the species
   group is provided, and photographs illustrate external morphology and
   male genitalia.

   Resources, Kamycka 129, Prague, CZ-16521, Czech Republic, Czech

DT Article
TI First record of the family Cantharidae on Socotra, with description of a
   new genus and two new species of the subfamily Silinae (Coleoptera:
   Elateroidea).
AU Geiser, Michael (m.geiser@nhm.ac.uk) 
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 57
SU S
PS 93-99
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The first known representatives of the family Cantharidae are described
   from Socotra: Silidius svihlai sp. nov. and Socotrasilis enigmatica gen.
   et sp. nov. Dorsal habitus, pronotum and aedeagus for each species are
   illustrated. Both species seem phylogenetically isolated, with no known
   close relatives.

   SW7 5BD, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.

DT Article
TI Bostrichidae (Coleoptera) of Socotra with description of two new
   subspecies.
AU Borowski, Jerzy (jerzy_borowski@sggw.pl) 
   Slawski, Marek
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 57
SU S
PS 101-111
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB New data on the occurrence of beetles of the family Bostrichidae on
   Socotra Island are presented-altogether nine species have been recorded
   hitherto. Besides faunistic data, the paper contains descriptions of two
   new subspecies: Enneadesmus obtusidentatus obscurior Borowski subsp.
   nov. and Enneadesmus forficula socotrensis Borowski subsp. nov. Both
   subspecies differ from nomino-typical forms in smaller size and
   distinctly shorter and less prominent tubercles and denticles on elytral
   truncation.

   Warsaw, PL-02776, Poland, Poland.

TI Cleridae (Coleoptera) from Socotra Island with description of new
   species.
AU Gerstmeier, Roland (r.gerstmeier@tum.de) 
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 57
SU S
PS 113-123
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Cleridae from Socotra Island are reviewed and five species are
   recorded. In addition to the cosmopolitan Necrobia rufipes (De Geer,
   1775), Wittmeridecus insularis sp. nov. (subfamily Tillinae), Opilo
   angustipennis sp. nov. and Opilo socotrensis sp. nov. (subfamily
   Clerinae) are described and illustrated. Opilo longipilis Fairmaire,
   1892 is newly recorded from Socotra.

DT Article
TI Colotrema socotrana sp nov from Socotra Island, with new records of the
   genus from Yemen (Coleoptera: Malachiidae).
AU Plonski, Isidor S. (isidor.plonski@gmx.at) 
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 57
SU S
PS 125-131
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Colotrema Wittmer, 1979 (Malachiidae: Malachiinae:
   Colotini) from Socotra Island is described and illustrated: Colotrema
   socotrana sp. nov. It is most similar to C. barbertonica Wittmer, 1991
   from South Africa, but differs from the latter in colouration of the
   extremities and morphology of maxillary palpi and terminalia. This
   species represents the first record of Colotrema for Socotra. In
   addition, C. asirensis Wittmer, 1979 and C. testacea wajjensis Wittmer,
   1980 are recorded from continental Yemen for the first time. A key to
   the species of Colotrema occurring in the Arabian Peninsula and in the
   Socotran Archipelago is given.
C1 Plonski, Isidor S.; Rembrandtstr 1-4, Vienna, A-1020, Austria, Austria.
EM isidor.plonski@gmx.at
SC Zoology
SN 0374-1036
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Colotrema [Asia / Arabian Peninsula / Key to species] [Yemen / Socotran
   Archipelago / ] [ / Socotra / New record]. 
   Colotrema asirensis; Colotrema testacea wajjensi [Yemen /  / New
   record]. 
   Colotrema socotrana [Yemen /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Cleroidea,
   Melyridae

   Peninsula & Yemen, Socotran Archipelago, P. 130; New record]. 
   Colotrema asirensis (Melyridae): [New record]. 
   Colotrema socotrana (Melyridae): [Sp nov, Yemen, P. 126].

DT Article
TI A taxonomic review of the genus Clitobius with description of a new
   species from Oman (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae).
AU Purchart, Lubos (lubos.purchart@post.cz) 
   Kaminski, Marcin Jan
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 57
SU S
PS 139-163
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Based on external and internal morphological characters, Apithesis obesa
   Waterhouse, 1881 (of the monotypical genus Apithesis Waterhouse, 1881)
   is redescribed and transferred from the tribe Ulomini to the tribe
   Opatrini where it is incorporated in Clitobius Mulsant & Rey, 1859.
   Preliminary review of the taxonomy and distribution of Clitobius is
   performed. The following names are placed in synonymy: Clitobius Mulsant
   & Rey, 1859 = Apithesis Waterhouse, 1881, syn. nov. = Apteroclitobius
   Koch, 1960, syn. nov.; Clitobius ovatus (Erichson, 1843) = Halonomus
   salinicola Wollaston, 1861, syn. nov.; Clitobius oblongiusculus
   (Fairmaire, 1875) = Clitobius ovatus borkouensis Pierre, 1961, syn.
   nov.; Clitobius obesus (Waterhouse, 1881), comb. nov. = Clitobius
   pseudalatus Koch, 1960, syn. nov. Clitobius omanicus sp. nov. is
   described from Oman. A key to the species of Clitobius is presented.
   Distributional patterns within the genus are analysed and discussed.
C1 Purchart, Lubos; Mendel Univ Brno, Dept Forest Ecol, Zemedelska 3, Brno,
   CZ-61300, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM lubos.purchart@post.cz

OI Purchart, Lubos/0000-0001-9958-2300

   Clitobius - Mulsant & Rey 1859 (Tenebrionidae): [Syn nov, Apithesis

   Clitobius obesus - (Waterhouse 1881) (Tenebrionidae): [Redescription, P.

DT Article
TI Longitarsus doeberli, a wingless new species from Socotra Island
   (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae).
AU Biondi, Maurizio (maurizio.biondi@univaq.it) 
   D'Alessandro, Paola
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 57
SU S
PS 165-172
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Longitarsus doeberli sp. nov. (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae: Galerucinae:
   Alticini), from Socotra Island is described. The new species is
   apparently similar to Longitarsus lederi Weise, 1889 from Caucasus with
   which it shares, in addition to compact body, some adaptive
   convergences, such as wingless condition and trend of reduction of the
   metatarsomere I. Based on the structure of the median lobe of aedeagus
   and the peculiar shape of the spermatheca, the new species shows instead
   the closest relationships with the species of the L. anchusae group,
   especially L. anchusae (Paykull, 1799) and L. anatolicus Weise, 1900.
C1 Biondi, Maurizio; Univ Aquila, Dept Hlth Life & Environm Sci, Coppito,
   I-67100, Italy, Italy.
EM maurizio.biondi@univaq.it
SC Zoology
SN 0374-1036
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Longitarsus doeberli [Yemen /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Chrysomelidae
OR Longitarsus doeberli (Chrysomelidae): [Sp nov, Yemen, P. 166].

TI A new species of Brachycerus from Socotra Island (Coleoptera:
   Curculionoidea: Brachyceridae).
AU Friedman, Ariel-Leib-Leonid (laibale@post.tau.ac.il) 
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 57
SU S
PS 173-182
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Brachycerus socotranus sp. nov., endemic to Socotra Island, is described
   from the three specimens collected by the Czech expeditions to Socotra
   in 2000-2012. The new species is characterized by prominent horn-like
   tubercles at the base of the rostrum, intact medial groove of pronotum
   with strongly prominent longitudinal carina and sexual dimorphism in the
   form of the apical part of the elytra.
C1 Friedman, Ariel-Leib-Leonid; Tel Aviv Univ, Steinhardt Museum Nat Hist,
   Tel Aviv, IL-69978, Israel, Israel.

   Eurasia; Asia

AN ZOOR15404025541
DT Article
TI Bees of the Socotra Archipelago (Hymenoptera: Anthophila), their
   biogeography and association with parasites.
AU Straka, Jakub (jakub.straka@aculeataresearch.com) 
   Batelka, Jan
   Pauly, Alain
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 57
SU S
PS 183-219
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Taxonomy of bees (Hymenoptera: Anthophila) of the Socotra Archipelago is
   evaluated based on historical and newly available specimens. Four new
   species of Halictidae are described from the Socotra Island: Austronomia
   socotrana Pauly & Straka sp. nov., Lasioglossum (Hemihalictus)
   boswelliae Pauly & Straka sp. nov., Lasioglossum (Sphecodogastra)
   dioscoridis Pauly & Straka sp. nov., and Lasioglossum (Ctenonomia)
   dracaenae Pauly & Straka sp. nov. The correct original spelling of
   Eucera wfkirbyi Kohl, 1906 is restored, Eucera kirbyi Friese, 1909 being
   its unjustified emendation and junior objective synonym. Identity of
   both Socotran species of Xylocopa Latreille, 1802 is clarified.
   Lasioglossum (Evylaeus) kowitense (Cockerell, 1937), Nomioides facilis
   (Smith, 1853), and Nomioides rotundiceps Handlirsch, 1888 are removed
   from the list of bees of Socotra. In total, 28 species in 16 genera are
   reported from the archipelago, of which nearly two thirds are considered
   endemic at the species level. Biogeographic origin of Socotran bees is
   analysed and proposed. Host associations with beetle parasites of the
   families Meloidae and Ripiphoridae (Coleoptera) and cleptoparasitic bees
   are evaluated for the Socotran bee fauna. Obligate bee parasitoid
   Ripiphorus arabiafelix arabiafelix Batelka, 2009 (Coleoptera:
   Ripiphoridae) is reported from the archipelago (Socotra Island) for the
   first time.

   Czech Republic, Czech Republic.

AN ZOOR15404021962
DT Article
TI Resurrection of genus Nidirana (Anura: Ranidae) and synonymizing N.
   caldwelli with N. adenopleura, with description of a new species from
   China.
AU Lyu, Zhi-Tong
   Zeng, Zhao-Chi
   Wang, Jian
   Lin, Chao-Yu
   Liu, Zu-Yao
   Wang, Ying-Yong (wangyy@mail.sysu.edu.cn) 
SO Amphibia-Reptilia
VL 38
IS 4
PS 483-502
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The taxonomy of Babina sensu lato was controversial in the past decades.
   In this study, the phylogeny of genus Babina sensu lato was
   re-constructed based on genetic analysis, morphological comparison and
   advertisement call analysis. We found that Babina sensu stricto and
   previous subgenus Nidirana should be two distinct genera in the family
   Ranidae. N. caldwelli is confirmed to be a synonym of N. adenopleura
   because of the small genetic divergence and the lack of distinct
   morphological differences. A new species, Nidirana nankunensis sp. nov.
   is described based on a series of specimens collected from Mt. Nankun,
   Guangdong Province, China, which can be distinguished from other known
   congeners by having a behavior of nest construction, distinctive
   advertisement calls, significant divergence in the mitochondrial genes,
   and a combination of morphological characters. Currently, the genus
   Babina contains two species and the genus Nidirana contains eight
   species.
C1 Wang, Ying-Yong; Sun Yat Sen Univ, Sch Life Sci, Guangzhou, Guangdong,
   510275, China, China.
EM wangyy@mail.sysu.edu.cn
OI Lyu, Zhi-Tong/0000-0002-4891-3859

SN 0173-5373; 1568-5381

   Reproduction; Reproductive behaviour; Genetics; Evolution; Behaviour;
   Communication; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   Dubois 1992, p. 494]. 
   Babina (Nidirana) - Dubois 1992 (Ranidae): [Raised to, Nidirana, p.

   Babina (Nidirana) okinavana - (Boettger 1895) (Ranidae): [Referred to,

PT J
AN ZOOR15404021964
DT Article
TI A new moth-preying alpine pit viper species from Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau
   (Viperidae, Crotalinae).
AU Shi, Jingsong (shijingsong@ivpp.ac.cn) 
   Wang, Gang
   Chen, Xi'er
   Fang, Yihao
   Ding, Li
   Huang, Song
   Hou, Mian
   Liu, Jun
   Li, Pipeng
SO Amphibia-Reptilia
VL 38
IS 4
PS 517-532
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB The Sanjiangyuan region of Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau is recognized as a
   biodiversity hotspot of alpine mammals but a barren area in terms of
   amphibians and reptiles. Here, we describe a new pit viper species,
   Gloydius rubromaculatus sp. n. Shi, Li and Liu, 2017 that was discovered
   in this region, with a brief taxonomic revision of the genus Gloydius.
   The new species can be distinguished from the other congeneric species
   by the following characteristics: cardinal crossbands on the back,
   indistinct canthus rostralis, glossy dorsal scales, colubrid-like oval
   head shape, irregular small black spots on the head scales, black eyes
   and high altitude distribution (3300-4770 m above sea level). The
   mitochondrial phylogenetic reconstruction supported the validity of the
   new species and furthermore reaffirms that G. intermedius changdaoensis,
   G. halys cognatus, G. h. caraganus and G. h. stejnegeri should be
   elevated as full species. Gloydius rubromaculatus sp. n. was found to be
   insectivorous: preying on moths (Lepidoptera, Noctuidae, Sideridis sp.)
   in the wild. This unusual diet may be one of the key factors to the
   survival of this species in such a harsh alpine environment.
C1 Shi, Jingsong; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Vertebrate Paleontol &
   Paleoanthropol, Beijing, 100044, China, China.
EM shijingsong@ivpp.ac.cn
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology
SN 0173-5373; 1568-5381
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Status;
   General morphology; Biochemistry; Genetics; Evolution; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Gloydius [General morphology /  / taxonomic revision] [Nucleic acids /
   Mitochondrial genome sequences / ] [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Phylogeny
   /  / ] [China / Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau / ]. 
   Gloydius rubromaculatus [Qinghai /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Serpentes, Viperidae
OR Gloydius - Hoge & Romano-Hoge 1981 (Viperidae). 
   Gloydius caraganus (Viperidae): [Raised from, Gloydius halys caraganus,
   p. 528]. 
   Gloydius changdaoensis - Li 1999 (Viperidae): [Raised from, Gloydius
   intermedius changdaoensis, p. 528]. 
   Gloydius cognatus (Viperidae): [Raised from, Gloydius halys cognatus, p.
   528]. 
   Gloydius halys caraganus (Viperidae): [Raised to, Gloydius caraganus, p.
   528]. 
   Gloydius halys cognatus (Viperidae): [Raised to, Gloydius cognatus, p.
   528]. 
   Gloydius halys stejnegeri (Viperidae): [Raised to, Gloydius stejnegeri,
   p. 528]. 
   Gloydius intermedius changdaoensis - Li 1999 (Viperidae): [Raised to,
   Gloydius changdaoensis, p. 528]. 
   Gloydius rubromaculatus - Shi, Li & Liu 2017 (Viperidae): [Sp nov,
   Qinghai, P. 522]. 
   Gloydius stejnegeri (Viperidae): [Raised from, Gloydius halys
   stejnegeri, p. 528]. 
   Gloydius strauchi species complex (Viperidae): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 525].

PT J
AN ZOOR15404023698
DT Article
TI A new species of Micragasma J. Sahlberg, 1900 (Coleoptera: Hydraenidae)
   from Crete.
AU Hernando, Carles
   Villastrigo, Adrian
   Ribera, Ignacio (ignacio.ribera@ibe.upf-csic.es) 
SO Aquatic Insects
VL 38
IS 4
PS 185-196
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe a new species of Micragasma J. Sahlberg, 1900 (Coleoptera,
   Hydraenidae), which is here treated as a subgenus of Ochthebius Leach,
   1815. The new species, O. (Micragasma) minoicus sp.n., was found at the
   margins of a coastal rockpool in the island of Crete. The species
   differs from the other two known species of Micragasma in both external
   and genital characters, but shares with them the presence of small
   setiferous tubercles on the surface of the head, pronotum and elytra,
   and a strong medial gibbosity on the head. In some characters, such as
   the structure and shape of the aedeagus, O. (M.) minoicus sp.n. is
   similar to other species of the genus Ochthebius, in particular of the
   subgenus Cobalius Rey, 1886, typical of coastal rockpools.
C1 Ribera, Ignacio; Univ Pompeu Fabra, CSIC, Barcelona, Spain, Spain.
EM ignacio.ribera@ibe.upf-csic.es
RI Villastrigo, Adrian/J-7614-2019
OI Villastrigo, Adrian/0000-0002-3531-0821
SC Zoology
SN 0165-0424
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Greece
DE Ochthebius (Micragasma) minoicus [Crete /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Hydraenidae
OR Ochthebius (Micragasma) minoicus (Hydraenidae): [Sp nov, Crete, P. 187].

DT Article
TI Two new taxa of the Subgenus Artapocyrtus Heller, 1912, Genus
   Metapocyrtus Heller, 1912 from the Philippines (Coleoptera,
   Curculionidae, Entiminae, Pachyrhynchini).
AU Bollino, Maurizio (m.bollino@tin.it) 
   Sandel, Franco
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 17
IS 1
PS 1-14
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB One new species and one new subspecies of the subgenus Artapocyrtus
   Heller, genus Metapocyrtus Heller (Entiminae: Pachyrhynchini) are
   described from northern Philippines, Luzon Island: M. (A.) lumawigi sp.
   n. and M. (A.) quadriplagiatus caeruleus ssp. nov. The diagnosis of each
   taxon is provided. Habitus photographs and illustrations of male and
   female genitalia are also given.

   Italy.

   Eurasia; Asia

   New subspecies].

TI A new species of the genus Aphrodisium Thomson, 1864 (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae) from the Philippines.
AU Kuleshov, Dmitry A. (ceramb@mail.ru)

VL 17

U1 0

AB The Oriental genus Aphrodisium Thompson, 1864 (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae)
   contains 37 species and 5 of them are known from Philippines. The sixth
   species A. nikitai sp.n. from the Philippines is described and

DT Article
TI Key to fossil Malthininae, with description of two new species in Baltic
   amber (Coleoptera Cantharidae).
AU Fanti, Fabrizio (fantifab@alice.it) 
   Vitali, Francesco
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 17
IS 1
PS 19-27
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The soldier beetles Malthodes caenozoicus n. sp. and Mimoplatycis
   bicolor n. sp. are described from Baltic amber. Malthodes caenozoicus n.
   sp. is characterised by small size, short elytra, and peculiar
   terminalia. Mimoplatycis bicolor n. sp. is characterised by peculiar
   pronotal ridges and coloration. A key to the fossil Malthininae is
   provided.
C1 Fanti, Fabrizio; Via Tamburino 69, Siena, I-53040, Italy, Italy.
EM fantifab@alice.it
OI Vitali, Francesco/0000-0003-3052-2910

SN 1407-8619

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene

   [Oligocene /  / ]. 
   Mimoplatycis bicolor [Oligocene /  / New species; Described from amber].
   
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

PT J
AN ZOOR15404025056
DT Article
TI A new coleopterous family Wabbelidae fam. nov. (Coleoptera: Cucujoidea)
   from Baltic amber (Cenozoic, Paleogene, Eocene).
AU Alekseev, Vitalii I. (alekseew0802@yahoo.com) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 17
IS 1
PS 29-41
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB An unknown peculiar beetle from Tertiary Baltic amber, Wabbel
   cerebricavus gen. et sp. nov. designated to a new family, is described
   and illustrated. The new family, Wabbelidae fam. nov., is diagnosed and
   assigned to the superfamily Cucujoidea. The new family can be identified
   by the thick moniliform antennae, modified (deeply concave) frons and
   vertex, longitudinally strigose pronotum with pair of basal grooves,
   wide gula with complete gular sutures, pentamerous non-lobed tarsi,
   seriate punctuation of elytra, and dorsally non-flattened body.
C1 Alekseev, Vitalii I.; FGBOU VO Kaliningrad State Tech Univ, Dept
   Zootechny, Sovetsky Av 1, Kaliningrad, 236000, Russia, Russia.
EM alekseew0802@yahoo.com
OI Alekseev, Vitalii/0000-0003-4390-5443
SC Zoology
SN 1407-8619
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Wabbel [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Wabbel cerebricavus [Russia /  / new species; Described from amber]
   [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Wabbelidae [Eocene /  / New family]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Cucujoidea
OR Cucujoidea (Polyphaga): [Key to families, Modified to include new
   family, p. 38]. 
   Wabbel (Cucujoidea): [Gen nov, Of new family Wabbelidae, Type species
   Wabbel cerebricavus, p. 30, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Wabbel cerebricavus (Cucujoidea): [Sp nov, Russia, Eocene, P. 30,
   Described from amber; Fossil]. 
   Wabbelidae (Cucujoidea): [Fam nov, Type genus Wabbel, p. 34, Eocene;
   Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15404025057
DT Article
TI First record of Cathartosilvanus Grouvelle (Coleoptera: Silvanidae) from
   Baltic amber with description of a new species.
AU Alekseev, Vitalii I. (alekseew0802@yahoo.com) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 17
IS 1
PS 43-48
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cathartosilvanus necromanticus sp. nov., the first fossil representative
   of the extant New World genus, is described and illustrated on the basis
   of an inclusion in European Eocene amber. The new taxon is characterised
   by comparatively large body size, pronotum elongate, with weakly
   produced anterior angles and obtuse basal angles, prosternal process not
   channeled, and elytra without tuberculate setiferous punctures.
C1 Alekseev, Vitalii I.; FGBOU VPO Kaliningrad State Tech Univ, Dept
   Zootechny, Sovetsky Av 1, Kaliningrad, 236000, Russia, Russia.
EM alekseew0802@yahoo.com
OI Alekseev, Vitalii/0000-0003-4390-5443
SC Zoology
SN 1407-8619

   Eurasia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Cathartosilvanus [Russia /  / first fossil record] [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Cathartosilvanus necromanticus [Russia /  / new species; Described from
   amber] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Cucujidae

TI Four new species of the genus Doliops Waterhouse, 1841 (Coleoptera:

AB Four new species of the genus Doliops Waterhouse, 1841 (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae) from Mindanao Island (the Philippines) are described and
   illustrated: D. cabrasae sp. n., D. imomzodai sp. n., D. ziedonisi sp.
   n. and D. rukmaneae sp. n. The genus Doliops in the world fauna is now
   represented by 54 species.

PT J
AN ZOOR15404025062
DT Article
TI A new species and new data of the genus Aristolebia Bates, 1892
   (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Lebiini).
AU Anichtchenko, Alexander (beetl2000@mail.ru) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 17
IS 2
PS 119-123
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the Lebiine genus Aristolebia Bates, 1892 from South
   Asia are described: A. saluki sp. nov. from India (Karnataka), and A.
   klimenkoi sp. nov. from Malaysia (Borneo). Both species are closely
   related to A. flavipennis Baehr, 2017 from Malaysia, but differ in the
   shape of the prothorax and elytra, and also in the colouration of the
   body and appendages. The male of A. apicalis Baehr, 2010 is described
   for the first time.
C1 Anichtchenko, Alexander; Daugavpils Univ, Inst Life Sci & Technol,
   Vienibas Iela 13, Daugavpils, LV-5401, Latvia, Latvia.
EM beetl2000@mail.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1407-8619
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Aristolebia klimenkoi [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
   Aristolebia saluki [Karnataka /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Aristolebia apicalis - Baehr 2010 (Carabidae): [First time described,
   Male, p. 123]. 
   Aristolebia klimenkoi (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 122]. 
   Aristolebia saluki (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Karnataka, P. 120].

DT Article
TI A peculiar new species of Diamella Shi & Liang, 2013 from Samar,
   Philippines (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Lebiini).
AU Anichtchenko, Alexander (beetl2000@mail.ru) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 17
IS 2
PS 125-127
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of carabid, Diamella singularis sp. n., is described from
   Samar island in the Philippines. It is easily distinguishable from all
   known species of the genus Diamella by the angulate lateral margins of
   its pronotum. Images of the habitus of the imago and aedeagus are given.
C1 Anichtchenko, Alexander; Daugavpils Univ, Inst Systemat Biol, Vienibas
   Iela 13-229, Daugavpils, LV-5400, Latvia, Latvia.

DT Article
TI A new genus and species of Physocrotaphini from New Guinea (Coleoptera:
   Carabidae: Anthiinae).
AU Anichtchenko, Alexander (beetl2000@mail.ru) 
   Sciaky, Riccardo
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 17
IS 2
PS 129-135
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Anguloderus gen. nov. and mirabilis n. sp. from Western Papua
   (Indonesia) is described. The new genus is distinguished from all known
   Physocrotaphini genera by a plurisetose ligula, combined with very large
   body size and very peculiar shape of pronotum. A new key to all the
   known genera of Physocrotaphini is proposed, along with some data about
   the mysterious genus Holoponerus Fairmaire, 1883.
C1 Anichtchenko, Alexander; Daugavpils Univ, Inst Life Sci & Technol,
   Vienibas Iela 13, Daugavpils, LV-5401, Latvia, Latvia.

   region; Eurasia; Asia

TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae

   Anguloderus mirabilis (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 131].

PT J
AN ZOOR15404025066
DT Article
TI Two new fossil species of Tillomorphites Vitali (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae) and remarks on the morphological evolution, mimicry,
   biogeography and phylogeny of the tribe Tillomorphini.
AU Vitali, Francesco (vitalfranz@cerambycoidea.com) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 17
IS 2
PS 147-160
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Tillomorphites Vitali, 2011 is revised with the description of
   two new species from Baltic Amber: Tillomorphites spinipes n. sp. and
   Tillomorphites otiliae n. sp. New observations and an improved
   reconstruction of Tillomorphites robustus Vitali, 2011 are provided. The
   typical characters of this genus are shared by the Ecuadorian extant
   species Euderces elachys Martins & Galileo, 2013 so that Tillomorphites
   elachys (Martins & Galileo, 2013) n. comb. is proposed. Biogeographical
   and biologic remarks on the genus Tillomorphites and on the phylogeny of
   Tillomorphini concerning distribution and morphologic evolution are
   hypothesised.
C1 Vitali, Francesco; 7a Rue JP Huberty, Luxembourg, L-1742, Luxembourg,
   Luxembourg.
EM vitalfranz@cerambycoidea.com
OI Vitali, Francesco/0000-0003-3052-2910

SN 1407-8619

   Taxonomic position; Key; Evolution; Variation; Zoogeography; Geological
   time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene

   species; Described from amber].

   148].

DT Article
TI Four new species and a new synonymy in the genus Doliops Waterhouse,
   1841 (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae) from Philippines.
AU Barsevskis, Arvids (arvids.barsevskis@du.lv) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 17
IS 2
PS 161-173
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of the genus Doliops Waterhouse, 1841 (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae) from Philippines are described and illustrated: D. boteroi
   sp. n. (Mindanao), D. dunskisi sp. n. (Mindanao), D. mindoroensis sp. n.
   (Mindoro) and D. santossilvai sp. n. (Mindanao) One synonymy is
   proposed: D. duodecimpunctata Heller, 1923 = D. gutowskii Barsevskis,
   2013 syn. n. The genus Doliops in the world fauna is now represented by
   57 species.
C1 Barsevskis, Arvids; Daugavpils Univ, Inst Life Sci & Technol, Vienibas

TI A new species of the genus Acronia Westwood, 1863 (Coleoptera:

AB Acronia layroni sp. nov. (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae: Lamiinae:
   Pteropliini) is described and illustrated. An updated check-list of the
   genus Acronia Westwood, 1863 is proposed. In biogeographical aspect, the
   largest diversity of species of Acronia are known from Luzon Island (9
   species), Mindanao Island (4 species), from Samar Island is known only

TI New species of the genus Pachyrhynchus Germar, 1824 (Coleoptera:
   Curculionidae) from Mindanao, Philippines.
AU Bollino, Maurizio (m.bollino@tin.it) 
   Sandel, Franco
   Rukmane, Anita
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 17
IS 2
PS 189-204
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Pachyrhynchus banglas sp. nov. and P. esperanza sp. nov., two new
   species of the Entiminae Pachyrhynchini genus Pachyrhynchus Germar, 1823
   (Curculionidae) from the Philippines, Mindanao Island, are described.
   Diagnosis of each taxon is provided, and habitus photographs and
   illustrations of male and female genitalia are given. The authors also
   propose a new taxonomical arrangement of two species groups:
   Pachyrhynchus amabilis species group and Pachyrhynchus schoenherri
   species group. The new synonymy: Pachyrhynchus elegans Waterhouse, 1842
   (= P. eos Heller, 1924, syn. n.) is also established.

LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB A second species of the genus Autaretia Strasser, 1978 (Diplopoda:
   Chordeumatida: Craspedosomatidae) has been discovered in a cave in the
   French Maritime Alps. The new species is described and an updated
   diagnosis of the genus is given. This interesting discovery improves our
   knowledge on the invertebrate fauna of the Maritime Alps, in particular
   of the Mercantour National Park, and is included as a new element in the
   checklist and atlas of the Diplopoda in France, in progress.

DT Article
TI A new species of genus Ganeo Klein, 1905 collected from Indus Valley
   Bullfrog Hoplobatrachus tigerinus (Anura: Dicroglossidae) of District
   Umerkot, Sindh, Pakistan.
AU Bushra, Attia
   Birmani, Nadir Ali
   Dharejo, Ali Murtaza
   Khan, Muhammad Munif
   Buriro, Saeeda Anjum
SO Biological Forum
VL 9
IS 2
PS 204-207
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A survey was conducted on the helminth parasites of Indus Valley
   Bullfrog Hoplobatrachus tigerinus of district Umerkot, Sindh, Pakistan.
   A total of 18 hosts were collected from different aquatic habitats and
   examined for the presence of helminth parasites. During examination of
   gut contents and visceral organs, three trematodes belonging to genus
   Ganeo Klein, 1905 were recovered from small intestine and identified as
   the Ganeo kabeeri n.sp. Present species differs from its congeners on
   the basis of the spinose body slightly tapering anteriorly; subterminal
   oral sucker larger than ventral sucker; shape of cirrus sac; shape and
   arrangement of testes; bilobed ovary attached with ventral sucker and
   posterior testis; distribution and extension of vitellaria; shape and
   extension of ceca and egg size.

PT J
AN ZOOR15404020340
DT Article
TI After the disaster: Bony fish remains (mostly otoliths) from the K/Pg
   boundary section at Stevns Klint, Denmark, reveal consistency with
   teleost faunas from later Danian and Selandian strata.
AU Schwarzhans, Werner (wwschwarz@aol.com) 
   Milan, Jesper
SO Bulletin of the Geological Society of Denmark
VL 65
PS 59-74
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This is the first study of bony fish remains across the K/Pg boundary
   section at Stevns Klint, Denmark. The studied specimens comprise one
   partly preserved articulated skeleton, a few isolated bones, and casts
   from several otolith imprints and voids. As otoliths are aragonitic, the
   remains are all dissolved. The imprints of the otoliths originate from
   the uppermost Maastrichtian Hojerup Member or 'Grey Chalk', and the bone
   fragments and the partial skeleton were obtained from the Fiskeler
   Member directly above the K/Pg boundary. Further otolith imprints
   originated from the basal Danian Cerithium Limestone Member, which
   directly overlies the Fiskeler Member. Three otolith-based taxa were
   identified from the uppermost Maastrichtian and six from the basal
   Danian. One of the species found in the uppermost Maastrichtian
   persisted into Danian times (Polymixia? harderi), a second represents a
   common genus in both Maastrichtian and Danian but cannot be identified
   to the species level (Centroberyx sp.), and a third taxon is an
   unidentifiable dynematichthyid, which, however, certainly does not
   belong to any of the known Danian dinematichthyid species. The species
   recognised in the basal Danian all persisted well into later Danian
   times or even the Selandian, showing a remarkable consistency of the
   early Paleocene bony fish fauna. We find no indication of phased
   extinction in the aftermath of the K/Pg boundary event in the data
   recovered from the Danian.
C1 Schwarzhans, Werner; Ahrensburger Weg 103, Hamburg, D-22359, Germany,
   Germany.
EM wwschwarz@aol.com
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0011-6297
BD Systematics; Sensory reception; Mechanoreception; Evolution; Ecology;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene; Mesozoic
DE Dinematichthyidae [Denmark / Stevns Klint / new record] [Cretaceous /
   Late Maastrichtian / ]. 
   Scorpaena corallophilus [Denmark / Stevns Klint / new record]
   [Palaeocene / Early Danian / ]. 
   Teleostei [Statoreceptors / Otoliths / systematics] [Extinction /
   Extinction event / ] [Fossil assemblages /  / ] [Denmark / Stevns Klint
   / stratigraphical distribution] [Palaeocene / Cretaceous boundary / ]
   [Cretaceous / Palaeogene boundary / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Ophidiiformes, Scorpaeniformes, Scorpaenidae
OR Teleostei (Actinopterygii): [Fossil]. 
   Dinematichthyidae (Ophidiiformes): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Scorpaena corallophilus (Scorpaenidae): [Fossil; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15404020340
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15404025195
DT Article
TI Three new species of Echinoderidae (Kinorhyncha: Cyclorhagida) from two
   seamounts and the adjacent deep-sea floor in the Northeast Atlantic
   Ocean.
AU Yamasaki, Hiroshi (h.yamasaki@meiobenthos.com) 
   Neuhaus, Birger
   George, Kai Horst
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 59
IS 1
PS 79-106
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of Echinoderes (Kinorhyncha: Cyclorhagida:
   Echinoderidae) are described from two Northeast Atlantic seamounts and
   the adjacent deep-sea floor. Echinoderes apex sp. nov. from the Great
   Meteor Seamount and the Sedlo Seamount is characterized by a combination
   of: a small trunk length (165-215 [mu]m); middorsal acicular spines on
   segments 4, 6, and 8; tubes ventrolaterally on segment 2,
   lateroventrally on segment 5, and laterodorsally on segment 10;
   lateroventral acicular spines on segments 6-9; long lateral terminal
   spines, 60.0-80.2% of trunk length; and type-2 glandular cell outlets
   subdorsally on segment 2, sublaterally on segment 6, and lateral
   accessorily on segment 8. Echinoderes bathyalis sp. nov. from the
   deep-sea floor near the Sedlo Seamount is characterized by a combination
   of: a small trunk length (224-243 [mu]m); middorsal acicular spines on
   segments 4-8 with a spine on segment 8 being very long (ca. 50% of trunk
   length); lateral accessory tubes on segment 5; lateroventral acicular
   spines on segments 6-9; and type-2 glandular cell outlets midlaterally
   on segment 2. Echinoderes meteorensis sp. nov. from the Great Meteor
   Seamount differs from its congeners in a combination of: a small trunk
   length (157-196 [mu]m); presence of middorsal acicular spines on
   segments 4, 6, and 8; tubes lateroventrally on segment 5, lateral
   accessorily on segment 8, and laterodorsally on segment 10;
   lateroventral acicular spines on segments 6-9; and type-2 glandular cell
   outlets in subdorsal and lateral accessory positions on segment 2.
   Echinoderes apex occurs on two seamount summits, whereas E. meteorensis
   occurs on one seamount summit, and no species occur both on a seamount
   summit and on the deep-sea floor.
C1 Yamasaki, Hiroshi; Leibniz Inst Evolut & Biodivers, Museum Nat Kunde,
   Invalidenstr 43, Berlin, D-10115, Germany, Germany.
EM h.yamasaki@meiobenthos.com
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 0007-9723

   zones; Atlantic Ocean

   Atlantic /  / New species]. 
   Kinorhyncha [Marine habitat / Seamounts / species diversity]
   [Zoogeography / Biogeography / ] [North Atlantic /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates

PT J
AN ZOOR15404020051
DT Article
TI First Isolation of Leptospira borgpetersenii from Fetuses of Wild Boars
   (Sus scrofa).
AU Brihuega, Bibiana
   Grune Loffler, Sylvia (grune.sylvia@inta.gob.ar) 
   Samartino, Luis
   Romero, Graciela
   Auteri, Carmelo
   Martinez, Mara
SO Electronic Journal of Biology
VL 13
IS 1
PS 63-66
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Leptospirosis is a worldwide zoonose and is endemic in many countries.
   This zoonosis is maintained in nature by chronic renal infection of
   carrier animals, being rodents and other small mammals the most
   important reservoirs. Also, significant sources of human infection are
   domestic animals, such as livestock and dogs. The wild boar (Sus scrofa)
   is an introduced species from Europe which is widespread in America and
   particularly in the Center and South of Argentina. This species is
   highly valued by hunters in the region and their meat is consumed more
   often. In many countries of the world (Europe, USA and Australia)
   studies of seroprevalence have been carried out, the seroreactivity does
   not mean that the wild boar has clinical symptoms of leptospirosis or
   that wild boars are maintenance host of this pathogen. However, these
   animals have been in contact to leptospiras in their environment in the
   past. This study has the objective of molecular characterization of
   pathogenic Leptospira sp. isolated strain obtained from fetuses of wild
   boars from Patagonia Argentina. Four fetuses were aborted from a wild
   boar (Sus scrofa) in Patagonia, the southern region of Argentina.
   Necropsy was performed of the 4 fetuses and samples of kidneys, liver,
   spleen and lung were cultivated in Fletcher and EMJH mediums. Also,
   samples of liver, spleen, lung and kidney of fetuses were processed and
   analyzed by direct immunofluorescence. Multiple Locus Variable number
   tandems repeats Analysis (MLVA) was used to characterize the isolated
   strain. The genetic profile of the isolated pathogenic Leptospira sp.
   strain was identical to the profile of Leptospira borgpetersenii serovar
   Castellonis Castellon 3. To the best of our knowledge this is the first
   isolation of Leptospira spp. from a wild boar fetus.
C1 Grune Loffler, Sylvia; Natl Inst Agr Technol, Lab Leptospirosis, Buenos
   Aires, DF, Argentina, Argentina.
EM grune.sylvia@inta.gob.ar
SC Infectious Diseases; Zoology
SN 1860-3122
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Diseases and disorders; Microbial
   diseases; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Sus scrofa [Bacterial diseases / Leptospira borgpetersenii / New record;
   pathology; molecular characterization] [Argentina / Patagonia / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Ungulates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Artiodactyla, Suidae
OR Sus scrofa (Suidae): [New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15404020051
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15404022258
DT Article
TI LIST OF TRUE BUG TAXA DESCRIBED BY RAUNO E. LINNAVUORI (HEMIPTERA:
   HETEROPTERA).
AU Kment, Petr
   Carapezza, Attilio (sigara@post.cz) 
SO Entomologica Americana
VL 122
IS 4
PS 528-621
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 1
U2 9
AB A list of 96 available genus-group taxa, 1459 available species-group
   taxa and 5 unavailable infrasubspecific taxa of Heteroptera described by
   Rauno E. Linnavuori is compiled. One new substitute name, Phytocoris
   (Eriamiris) rostriformis nom. nov., is proposed to replace the junior
   homonym Phytocoris rostratus Linnavuori, 2000b (Miridae). Taylorilygus
   nairobiensis nigricollis Linnavuori, 1974a is recognized as an available
   name and senior objective synonym of Taylorilygus nairobiensis
   atricollis Linnavuori, 1975f, syn. nov. (Miridae). Lectotype of
   Taylorilygus nairobiensis nigricollis is designated. Two new
   combinations are proposed: Chinavia amosi (Linnavuori, 1982) comb. nov.
   and Chinavia aequalis (Linnavuori, 1972) comb. nov. (both transferred
   from the genus Acrosternum Fieber, 1860) (Pentatomidae). Status of
   Sciocoris (Neosciocoris) othmanus Linnavuori, 1972 as synonym of
   Sciocoris (Neosciocoris) conspurcatus Klug, 1845 is confirmed. Placement
   of Orthotylus problematicus Linnavuori, 1953b (Miridae) in the
   nominotypical subgenus Orthotylus Fieber, 1858 is confirmed based on
   examination of male genitalia. Tuponia (Tuponia) luniensis Linnavuori,
   1974c (Miridae) is placed in the nominotypical subgenus Tuponia Reuter,
   1875. Paralaemocoris (Laemocoris) linnavuorii Kerzhner, 1970 (=
   Paralaemocoris (Laemocoris) ahngeri Reuter, 1901, misidentification) is
   formally designated as type species of the subgenus Laemocorella
   Linnavuori, 1964 (Miridae), and Afraethus bistortus Linnavuori, 1993 (=
   Aethus pallipennis Dallas, 1851, misidentification) is formally
   designated as type species of the genus Afraethus Linnavuori, 1977
   (Cydnidae), both by action of the First Reviser according to Articles
   70.3 and 70.3.2 of ICZN (1999). Metacanthus linnavuorii Pe ' ricart,
   1976 (Berytidae) is found to be an unavailable name. The type status
   (syntype / holotype / lectotype) and/ or the first publication of the
   name as available is clarified for the following taxa: Cryptostemma
   (Harpago) castaneovitreus Linnavuori, 1951b (Dipsocoridae), Hebrus
   (Hebrus) ilaira Cobben and Linnavuori, 1981 in Linnavuori (1981)
   (Hebridae), Aloea Linnavuori, 1975f, Bowdenella gloriosa Linnavuori,
   1974e, Bowdenella hirtula Linnavuori, 1974e, Collaria nigra Linnavuori,
   1974f, Horvathiella umbrina Linnavuori, 1974e, Oreolygus Linnavuori,
   1975f, Orthotylus junipericolus frigidus Linnavuori, 1974e, Orthotylus
   junipericolus junipericolus Linnavuori, 1974e, Orthotylus maesae
   Linnavuori, 1974e, Orthotylus rubidus Linnavuori, 1974e, Orthotylus
   viridipennis Linnavuori, 1974e, Paurolygus ciliaris Linnavuori, 1974e,
   Pilophorus erraticus Linnavuori, 1962e, Pleurochilophorus rubrinervis
   Linnavuori, 1974f, Psallus senjoensis Linnavuori, 1961f, Yambio
   Linnavuori, 1975f, Yambio chaetacme Linnavuori, 1974e, Yambio
   clavicornis Linnavuori, 1974e (all Miridae), Holotrichius nitidicollis
   Linnavuori, 1964a (Reduviidae), Myla abyssinia Linnavuori, 1971e, Myla
   graciloides Linnavuori, 1971e (Coreidae), Geocoris paradoxus Linnavuori,
   1954a, Geocoris paradoxus var. punctiger Linnavuori, 1954a (Geocoridae),
   Acrosternum aequale Linnavuori, 1972f, Acrosternum apicale Linnavuori,
   1972f, Durmia circe Linnavuori, 1972 in Gillon (1972) (Pentatomidae),
   and Rhyparochromus rugulosus Linnavuori, 1954a (Rhyparochromidae). The
   exact dates of publication are corrected for the following taxa:
   Micracanthia imitator Linnavuori, 1952 (Saldidae), Sphinctothorax
   striatulus Linnavuori, 1973 (Miridae), Horvathiolus rhea Linnavuori and
   Al-Safadi, 1994, Pylorgus alkithoe Linnavuori and Al-Safadi, 1994 (both
   Lygaeidae), Engistus exsanguis punctulatus Linnavuori, 1954a, Geocoris
   paradoxus Linnavuori, 1954a, Geocoris paradoxus var. punctiger
   Linnavuori, 1954a (all Geocoridae), Dinomachus aksiokhe Linnavuori and
   Al-Safadi, 1994, Trinithignus manto Linnavuori and AlSafadi, 1994 (both
   Heterogastridae), Elasmolomus mahfid Linnavuori and Al-Safadi, 1994,
   Emblethis angustus var. dubius Linnavuori, 1954a, Emblethis brachypterus
   Linnavuori, 1954a, Gonianotus angusticollis Linnavuori, 1954a,
   Rhyparochromus chiragra cyprius Linnavuori, 1954a, and Rhyparochromus
   rugulosus Linnavuori, 1954a (all Rhyparochromidae). Mandatory changes
   are made to correct the gender agreement of 50 species-group names in
   the genus Campylomma Reuter, 1878 and 34 species group-names in the
   genus Miyomma Puton, 1872 (both Miridae), as well as of Campyloneuropsis
   falcigera (Linnavuori, 1975), Darfuromma vulneratum Linnavuori, 1975,
   Hallodapus katanganus (Linnavuori, 1973), Leptopterna dentifera
   Linnavuori, 1970, Nesidiocoris montivagus (Linnavuori, 1975), Paloniella
   nigra (Linnavuori, 1975) (Miridae), Psilolomia amphrysius (Linnavuori,
   1970) (Coreidae), Durmia sallierdupini devia Linnavuori, 1982, Kayesia
   setigera Linnavuori, 1982 (Pentatomidae) and Pseudopachybrachius
   capicola (Stal, 1874) (Rhyparochromidae). Type depositories for many
   species described by R. Linnavuori himself or by other authors based on
   his collection are provided and corrected.
C1 Carapezza, Attilio; Via Sandro Botticelli 15, Palermo, I-90144, Italy,

AN ZOOR15404022260
DT Article
TI LIST OF CICADOMORPHA TAXA DESCRIBED BY RAUNO E. LINNAVUORI (HEMIPTERA:
   AUCHENORRHYNCHA).
AU Lemaitre, Valerie A. (v.lemaitre@nhm.ac.uk) 
   McKamey, Stuart H.
   Kment, Petr
SO Entomologica Americana
VL 122
IS 4
PS 632-729
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB A list of 19 family-group, 206 available genus-group, 1267 available and
   16 unavailable speciesgroup taxa of Cicadomorpha described by Rauno E.
   Linnavuori is compiled. The following 18 taxa were originally proposed
   as unavailable infrasubspecific names, being either published in papers
   describing forms and varieties along with subspecies or being
   established after 1960: Aphrophora alni f. umbrina Linnavuori, 1950d,
   Bahita infuscata var. fratercula Linnavuori, 1959 (made available from
   the original description due to the action of Linnavuori and DeLong,
   1978a: 124), Bahita palliditarsis f. flavicollis Linnavuori, 1959,
   Empoasca colorata var. rubropunctata Linnavuori, 1960a, Erythroneura
   leveri var. kraussi Linnavuori, 1960b (validated here as Kanguza kraussi
   Lemai (BOOLEAN AND) tre, McKamey and Kment sp. nov.), Erythroneura
   nayavua var. rewanoides Linnavuori, 1960b (validated here as Bogorya
   rewanoides Lemaitre, McKamey and Kment sp. nov.), Exitianus
   obscurinervis f. nigellus Linnavuori, 1959, Graminella stelliger var.
   punctipes Linnavuori, 1959 (made available from the original description
   due to the action of Kramer, 1967a), Hecalus eximius f. reticulatus
   Linnavuori, 1962a (described again as Hecalus reticulatus Linnavuori,
   1975a), Nesophrosyne argentatus var. distans Linnavuori, 1960a,
   Osbornellus blantoni f. unilineatus Linnavuori, 1959, Stirellus picinus
   f. mancus Linnavuori, 1959, Tetartostylus parabolatus var. spinosus
   Linnavuori, 1961a (validated as Tetartostylus parabolatus spinus McKamey
   and Hicks, 2007), Texanus apicalis f. contaminatus Linnavuori, 1959
   (validated here as Texanus (Iowanus) contaminatus Lemai (BOOLEAN AND)
   tre, McKamey and Kment sp. nov.), Xestocephalus purpurascens var. mendax
   Linnavuori, 1960b, Xestocephalus purpurascens var. taeniatus Linnavuori,
   1960b, Xestocephalus vitiensis var. mancus Linnavuori, 1960b,
   Xestocephalus vitiensis var. triceros Linnavuori, 1960b. The original
   misidentification of the type species for Neophlepsius Linnavuori, 1955d
   is removed by action of first reviser by establishing here Phlepsius
   gracilis non Osborn, 1923 sensu Linnavuori (1955d) Neophlepsius
   corpulentus Linnavuori, 1959 as the type species. Xestocephalus izzardi
   vuorinoelieae Lemai (BOOLEAN AND) tre, McKamey and Kment nom. nov., a
   new replacement name for Xestocephalus izzardi dissimilis is
   established. Balclutha dubiosa Linnavuori, 1975d is considered an
   available name. The correct original spelling of Agalliopsis puntana
   Linnavuori and DeLong, 1979d and Mbolokoa Linnavuori, 1972d is
   established. The grammatical gender of the following genera is fixed:
   Alloproctus Bergroth, 1924 (masculine), Concepciona Linnavuori and
   DeLong, 1977c (masculine), Consepusa Linnavuori and DeLong, 1977c
   (feminine), Maichewia Linnavuori and Al-Ne'amy, 1983 (feminine),
   Menosoma Ball, 1931 (neuter), and Pediopsoides Matsumura, 1912
   (masculine). The gender agreement of Alloproctus placidus (Evans, 1957),
   Alloproctus fernandezanus (Linnavuori and DeLong, 1977c), Batracomorphus
   roridus (Linnavuori, 1956e), Macropsis aspera Linnavuori, 1978a,
   Maichewia aspera Linnavuori and Al-Ne'amy, 1983, Menosoma cinctum
   (Osborn & Ball, 1898), Menosoma flavolineatum Linnavuori & DeLong,
   1978d, Menosoma neocinctum (Osborn, 1923), Menosoma pictum Zanol, 1989,
   Menosoma pseudotaeniatum Linnavuori & DeLong, 1978a, Menosoma taeniatum
   Linnavuori, 1955d, Pediopsoides (Pediopsoides) albus Li, Dai & Li, 2016,
   Pediopsoides (Pediopsoides) amplificatus Li, Dai & Li, 2016,
   Pediopsoides (Pediopsoides) bispinatus Li, Dai & Li, 2012, Pediopsoides
   (Celopsis) dapitanus (Merino, 1936), Pediopsoides (Pediopsoides)
   femoratus (Hamilton, 1980), Pediopsoides (Pediopsoides) kodaianus
   Viraktamath, 1996, Pediopsoides (Celopsis) pectinatus (Viraktamath,
   1996), Pediopsoides (Kiamoncopsis) serratus (Linnavuori, 1978), and
   Pediopsoides (Kiamoncopsis) testaceus (Linnavuori, 1978) is corrected.
   The correct original spellings of Chlorotettix hamula DeLong and
   Linnavuori, 1979, Chlorotettix orbicula DeLong and Linnavuori, 1979,
   Nicolaus camena (Linnavuori, 1969), and Terulia curvistylus (Linnavuori,
   1956a) are also restored. The authorship and original publication of
   Hecalus reticulatus Linnavuori, 1975a (not Linnavuori, 1962a) and
   Neopsinae Linnavuori, 1977 in Linnavuori and DeLong (1977c) (not
   Linnavuori, 1978a) are corrected. The exact dates of publication are
   corrected for the following Cicadellidae taxa: Empoasca abstrusa
   Linnavuori, 1950a (Kybos abstrusus (Linnavuori, 1950a)), Typhlocyba
   decempunctata intercedens Linnavuori, 1950a (= Linnavuoriana intercedens
   (Linnavuori, 1950a)) (the year was previously stated as 1949) and
   Parallaxis colorata Linnavuori, 1955a, Parallaxis imitans Linnavuori,
   1955a, Parallaxis praenubila Linnavuori, 1955a and Omskius Linnavuori,
   1955b (the year was previously stated as 1954). The type status (syntype
   /holotype / lectotype) and type depositories for some species are
   discussed and clarified. Lectotype designations made before 2000 using
   incorrectly the term (holo) type are accepted for Batracomorphus
   jimmaensis Heller and Linnavuori, 1968, Mileewa bifurcata Heller and
   Linnavuori, 1968, Stragania persimilis Linnavuori, 1956a (= Julipopa
   persimilis (Linnavuori, 1956)) and Stragania rorida Linnavuori, 1956e (=
   Batracomorphus roridus). A list of 169 species- group taxa described by
   Irena Dworakowska based on specimens from Rauno Linnavuori's collection
   is also provided to rectify the current placement of its holotypes.
C1 Lemaitre, Valerie A.; Nat Hist Museum, Dept Life Sci Insects, Cromwell
   Rd, London, SW7 5BD, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.

DT Article
TI Callionymus boucheti, a new species of dragonet from New Ireland, Papua
   New Guinea, western Pacific Ocean, with the description of a new
   subgenus (Teleostei: Callionymidae).
AU Fricke, Ronald (ronfricke@web.de) 
SO FishTaxa
VL 2
IS 4
PS 180-194
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Callionymus boucheti sp. nov. from northern New Ireland Province, Papua
   New Guinea, is described on the basis of seven specimens collected with
   dredges and trawls in about 72-193 m depth between northeastern New
   Hanover and off Kavieng. The new species is characterised within
   Margaretichthys subgen. nov. by a short head (3.5-3.7 in standard
   length); eye large (2.5-3.0 in head length); preopercular spine with a
   short, straight main tip, 5-7 curved serrae on its dorsal margin and a
   strong antrorse spine at its base, ventral margin smooth, slightly
   convex; first dorsal fin in male much higher than second dorsal fin, in
   female as high as second dorsal fin, with 4 spines, first spine with a
   long filament (male) or without a filament (female); second dorsal-fin
   distally straight, with 9 unbranched rays (last divided at base); anal
   fin with 8 unbranched rays (last divided at base); 21-23 pectoral-fin
   rays; caudal fin elongate, much longer in male than in female, nearly
   symmetrical (upper rays not much shorter than lower rays); no dark
   blotch near pectoral-fin base; first dorsal fin in male dark grey,
   anteriorly with oblique white streaks, posteriorly with white spots, in
   female also with a black blotch distally near third spine; anal fin
   distally black, margin of black area straight, black area wider in male
   than in female; caudal fin in male with 18-22 vertical streaks (in
   female with 8-11 vertical streaks); pelvic fin pale, without spots. The
   new species is compared with similar species. A key to the five species
   of Margaretichthys subgen. nov. is presented.
C1 Fricke, Ronald; Ramstal 76, Lauda Konigshofen, D-97922, Germany,
   Germany.
EM ronfricke@web.de
SC Zoology
SN 2458-942X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Key; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Callionymus (Margaretichthys) boucheti [South Pacific / Papua New Guinea
   / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Callionymidae
OR Callionymus (Margaretichthys) (Callionymidae): [Subgen nov, Type species
   Callionymus margaretae Regan 1905, p. 183; Key to species, P. 186]. 
   Callionymus (Margaretichthys) boucheti (Callionymidae): [Sp nov, Papua
   New Guinea (marine), P. 187]. 
   Callionymus australis - Fricke 1983 (Callionymidae): [Referred to, New
   subgenus Callionymus (Margaretichthys), p. 185]. 
   Callionymus margaretae - Regan 1905 (Callionymidae): [Designated type
   species for new subgenus, Callionymus (Margaretichthys), p. 183]. 
   Callionymus rivatoni - Fricke 1993 (Callionymidae): [Referred to, New
   subgenus Callionymus (Margaretichthys), p. 185]. 
   Callionymus sereti - Fricke 1998 (Callionymidae): [Referred to, New
   subgenus Callionymus (Margaretichthys), p. 186].

PT J
AN ZOOR15404025361
DT Article
TI Two new species of Psilorhynchus (Teleostei: Psilorhynchidae) from Bihar
   and Uttar Pradesh, India.
AU Arunachalam, Muthukumarasamy (arunacm@cukerala.ac.in) 
   Vijayakumar, Chinniyan
   Mayden, Richard L.
SO FishTaxa
VL 2
IS 4
PS 210-225
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Species of Psilorhynchus are small stream and river dwelling fishes that
   are currently known from India, Nepal, Myanmar, and Bangladesh. While
   once considered a relatively depauperate genus, several new species have
   been described over the past decade. This increase in the number of
   species has come from an increasing number of expeditions to areas
   poorly inventoried or never sampled before, museum holdings containing
   previously unrecognized species, and significant efforts by some
   scientists working on the group. The genus was once placed in the family
   Cyprinidae, one of the largest families of freshwater fishes, but was
   removed to its own family Psilorhynchidae based on phylogenetic
   relationships relative to other groups also placed in Cyprinidae. Recent
   research expeditions of the rivers and streams of India resulted in the
   discovery of two additional new species of Psilorhynchus. Herein, we
   describe two species, P. platydorsalis, from Bihar, and P. kuwana, from
   Uttar Pradesh, and compare them to other species of the genus.
C1 Arunachalam, Muthukumarasamy; Cent Univ Kerala, Dept Anim Sci, Riverside
   Transit Campus, Kasaragod, Kerala, 671314, India, India.
EM arunacm@cukerala.ac.in
SC Zoology
SN 2458-942X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Documentation; Publications; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Psilorhynchus [Checklists /  / Systematics] [India /  / ]. 
   Psilorhynchus kuwana [Uttar Pradesh /  / New species]. 
   Psilorhynchus platydorsalis [Bihar /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Psilorhynchidae
OR Psilorhynchus - McClelland 1839 (Psilorhynchidae). 
   Psilorhynchus kuwana (Psilorhynchidae): [Sp nov, Uttar Pradesh, P. 218].
   
   Psilorhynchus platydorsalis (Psilorhynchidae): [Sp nov, Bihar, P. 211]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15404025361
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15404023431
DT Article
TI Breviclypeus, a new South African Trichiina genus (Coleoptera:
   Scarabaeidae, Cetoniinae).
AU Ricchiardi, Enrico (alericor@fastwebnet.it) 
   Perissinotto, Renzo
   Clennell, Lynette
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 49
IS 2
PS 125-132
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus, Breviclypeus gen. nov., endemic to South Africa, is
   erected. The type species is here designated to be Agenius rufipennis
   Gory & Percheron 1833 (comb. nov.). A second species, Campulipus
   plagosus (Peringuey, 1885) is recognized to belong into this new genus
   (comb. nov.). Consequently, the genus Campulipus Kirby, 1827 is now
   represented by three species only, Campulipus limbatus (Olivier, 1789),
   Campulipus clavus (Schaum, 1844) and Campulipus suturalis (Waterhouse,
   1885). A fourth taxon, Agenius nobilis J. Thomson, 1878 is here
   transferred to Campulipus (comb. nov.) and synonymized with C. limbatus
   (syn. nov.) The two genera not only exhibit key morphological
   differences, but also occupy different habitats and diverge
   substantially in their ecology. An updated key of the genera of South
   African Trichiina is also provided. A separate key is provided for the
   genus Breviclypeus.
C1 Ricchiardi, Enrico; Corso A Tassoni 79-4, Turin, I-10143, Italy, Italy.
EM alericor@fastwebnet.it
SC Zoology
SN 0429-288X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Trichiina [South Africa /  / Key to genera]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Scarabaeoidea,
   Scarabaeidae
OR Agenius nobilis - J. Thomson 1878 (Scarabaeidae): [Referred to,
   Campulipus, p. 125]. 
   Agenius plagosus - Peringuey 1885 (Scarabaeidae): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Breviclypeus, p. 127; Lectotype designated, P.
   129]. 
   Breviclypeus - Ricchiardi 2017 (Scarabaeidae): [Gen nov, Of subtribe
   Trichiina, Type species Agenius plagosus Peringuey 1885, p. 127; Key to
   species, P. 132]. 
   Breviclypeus plagosus - (Peringuey 1885) (Scarabaeidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Campulipus, p. 129]. 
   Breviclypeus rufipennis - (Gory & Percheron 1833) (Scarabaeidae): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Campulipus, p. 130]. 
   Campulipus limbatus - (Olivier 1789) (Scarabaeidae): [Syn nov,
   Campulipus nobilis (J. Thomson 1878), p. 125]. 
   Campulipus nobilis - (J. Thomson 1878) (Scarabaeidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Agenius, p. 125]. 
   Campulipus plagosus - (Peringuey 1885) (Scarabaeidae): [Referred to, New
   genus Breviclypeus, p. 129]. 
   Campulipus rufipennis - (Gory & Percheron 1833) (Scarabaeidae):
   [Referred to, New genus Breviclypeus, p. 130]. 
   Trichiina (Scarabaeidae): [Key to genera, South Africa, Updated key, p.
   131].

TI A new species of Typhonia from the Ligurian Alps (Lepidoptera:
   Psychidae).
AU Bertaccini, Edgardo (edgardobertaccini@gmail.com) 
   Zilli, Alberto
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 49
IS 2
PS 137-144
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Typhonia lailae sp. n. is described on basis of samples from the
   Ligurian Alps (NW Italy). The new species is a member of the Typhonia
   ciliaris-melana complex and though it seems closest to T. melana (=
   beatricis) by the thick antennae of the female, DNA-barcode analysis
   places it nearest to T. ciliaris.

   Italy, Italy.

AN ZOOR15404023434
DT Article
TI Two new Lamiogethes Audisio & Cline from China (Coleoptera: Nitidulidae,
   Meligethinae).
AU Liu, Meike
   Huang, Min (liumk2009@126.com) 
   Cline, Andrew Richard
   Audisio, Paolo
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 49
IS 2
PS 145-150
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new species of the genus Lamiogethes Audisio & Cline, 2009 are
   described from China (Sichuan): L. forcipenis sp. n., and L.
   convexistrigosus sp. n., based on a series of recently collected
   specimens. The new species are both likely morphologically related to L.
   potanini (Kirejtshuk, 1979) from Sichuan and to L. conjungens
   (Grouvelle, 1910) from Yunnan. These new species clearly differ from
   their related taxa by details of the body shape and color, and the
   distinct shape of the male and female genitalia. Both new species are
   likely associated as larvae with a member of the genus Phlomoides Moench
   (Lamiaceae).
C1 Huang, Min; Northwest A & F Univ, Entomol Museum, Yangling, Shaanxi,
   712100, China, China.
EM liumk2009@126.com
SC Zoology
SN 0429-288X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China

   Lamiogethes forcipenis [Sichuan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Cucujoidea,
   Nitidulidae
OR Lamiogethes convexistrigosus (Nitidulidae): [Sp nov, Sichuan, P. 147]. 
   Lamiogethes forcipenis (Nitidulidae): [Sp nov, Sichuan, P. 146].

DT Article
TI Hesperoides, a new 'hairy' flea beetle genus from southern Africa
   (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae, Galerucinae, Alticini).
AU Biondi, Maurizio (maurizio.biondi@univaq.it) 
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 49
IS 2
PS 151-158
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Hesperoides afromeridionalis gen. nov. and sp. nov. from the Republic of
   South Africa (Western and Eastern Cape Provinces and KwaZulu-Natal) is
   described. Despite some similarities with Hespera Weise, it exhibits
   major affinities with the genera attributed to the subtribe Aphthonini,
   especially with Aphthona Chevrolat and Montiaphthona Scherer. Data on
   distribution are supplied, along with preliminary ecological notes.
   Photomicrographs of main morphological characters, including male and
   female genitalia, and metafemoral extensor tendon are provided. Key to
   the six "hairy" flea beetle genera occurring in sub-Saharan African and
   their habitus photos are also given.
C1 Biondi, Maurizio; Univ Aquila, Dept Life Hlth & Environm Sci, Via Vetoio
   Snc, Laquila, I-67100, Italy, Italy.
EM maurizio.biondi@univaq.it

SN 0429-288X

   Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Chrysomelidae [Africa / sub-Saharan Africa / Key to genera]. 
   Hesperoides afromeridionalis [South Africa /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Chrysomelidae

   Africa, P. 156].

TI Two new African and Madagascan species of the genus Holochlora
   (Orthoptera: Tettigoniidae, Phaneropterinae).
AU Massa, Bruno (bruno.massa@unipa.it) 
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 49
IS 2
PS 165-169
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species, Holochlora mauritiana and H. ingrischi from the island
   of Mauritius and Zimbabwe, respectively, are described. Along with a
   third species, H. biloba Stal, 1874 from Madagascar, they are the sole
   African representatives of the mostly Oriental genus Holochlora Stal,
   1873, including ca. 60 taxa distributed from India to China. Preliminary
   hypotheses on biogeographical and evolutionary origin of Afro-Madagascan
   Holochlora species are shortly discussed.
C1 Massa, Bruno; Univ Palermo, Dept Agr Food & Forest Sci, Viale Sci,Bldg
   4A, Palermo, I-90128, Italy, Italy.
EM bruno.massa@unipa.it

   Africa; Oceanic islands; Indian Ocean islands

   Holochlora mauritiana (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Mauritius, P. 166].

DT Article
TI The genus Anterhynchium in the Philippine Islands (Hymenoptera:
   Vespidae, Eumeninae).
AU Selis, Marco (marcozetsu@hotmail.it) 
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 49
IS 2
PS Ento175-178
PD 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A taxonomic study on the genus Anterhynchium de Saussure, 1863 from the
   Philippine Islands is presented. Two species are recorded: A.
   astrophilum Giordani Soika, 1996 and A. townesi van der Vecht, 1963.
   Anterhynchium astrophilum is recorded for the first time since its
   description, A. flavomarginatum townesi is raised to species rank (A.
   townesi stat. nov.) and its unknown male is described. A key to the
   species and new distributional records are provided.
C1 Selis, Marco; Via Tarquini 22, Viterbo, I-01100, Italy, Italy.
EM marcozetsu@hotmail.it
SC Zoology
SN 0429-288X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Taxonomy; Status; Key; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Anterhynchium [Philippines /  / Key to species] [ /  / Distribution;
   systematics]. 
   Anterhynchium (Dirhynchium) townesi [Philippines / Mindanao & Mindoro /
   New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Vespoidea, Eumenidae
OR Anterhynchium - de Saussure 1863 (Eumenidae): [Key to species,
   Philippines, P. 175]. 
   Anterhynchium (Dirhynchium) flavomarginatum townesi - van der Vecht 1963
   (Eumenidae): [Raised to, Anterhynchium (Dirhynchium) townesi, p. 176]. 
   Anterhynchium (Dirhynchium) townesi - van der Vecht 1963 (Eumenidae):
   [First time described, Male, p. 177; Raised from, Anterhynchium
   (Dirhynchium) flavomarginatum townesi, p. 176; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15404023439
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17
